reviewText:
Long story short: It's a copy and paste port of Quake's Deathmatch mode into Valve's Goldsource engine with less maps, less mods, and no singleplayer. Skip it and grab Quake instead.
DISCLAIMER: As an Australian, the playerbase is almost non-existant. While playable with 4 to 8 friends, you won't enjoy this game as much if you're by yourself.

Deathmatch Classic is essentially just a deathmatch type game mode using Quake's weapons (and some of its maps). It feels like it was an experiment to recreate Quake inside Valve's new engine than anything else, because it lacks any sort of content unique to the experience.

Not that there's anything wrong with this game: Quake's multiplayer is some of the best there is. There's a bunch of cool weapons, each for different playstyles and situations, and the maps give a nice sense of dynamic movement. It's quick, fast, and tonnes of fun.

The issue here is that Deathmatch Classic doesn't add anything other than a couple of maps. They're still good, but the issue is that for $5, you're playing a thinned down experience of the multiplayer portion of an 18 year old game that is available on the same platform. As part of the Counter-Strike 1 Anthology, it's an okay bonus, but as a standalone title it's not worth the price.

reviewText:
Much to my personal dismay, Deathmatch Classic has no reason to be recommended. Deathmatch Classic is the original QuakeWorld, but in the GoldSrc (Half-life 1, Counter strike 1.6) engine, most of the maps are great redesigns of Quake's deathmatch maps that still impress me despite its age (I have a thing for castles/churches with compressed jpegs for skyboxes), However not only is the gameplay slower due to its engine, but its playerbase is as dead as Ricochet's.
Deathmatch Classic was clearly not meant to be a best-seller but a shoutout to id software and their breakthrough in PC gaming in terms of multiplayer thanks to QuakeWorld and Doom deathmatch.

If you want the Deathmatch Classic experience, save your five bucks, go download Quake Live, and play it until bethesda decides to demand subscription money for every time you push a button mid-game.

reviewText:
Deathmatch Classic is Valve’s first game in their “Classic” series which consists of games that are either an homage or just related to the game Quake in one way or another, why? I’m still not sure, but I can only assume it’s because Valve loves Quake.

The game takes all your favorite Quake deathmatch arenas and puts them into source, while still replicating all of the weapons from Quake and having the same placement around the maps for players to pick up and use.

Just like Half-Life you can select your model to use while playing, and of course it’s all Half-Life characters. So what is this game then? Is it a Half-Life and Quake crossover? Well not really, because there’s nothing in the game that even says Quake or shows the Quake emblem and all the powerups such as Quad damage are replaced with the lambda. It’s just Quake Multiplayer reformed into Half-Life.

So Valve made an online deathmatch shooter focused multiplayer game, even though they just replicated Quake and treated it like a tribute, they didn’t even bother to fix the problems it already suffered from previously
All the weapons are incredibly unbalanced to where it’s just Rocket Launcher: The Game, really. They didn’t change any of the weapons from Quake at all.
In Quake’s singleplayer the regular shotgun is made to do a set amount of damage to enemies who have a set amount of health, so that’d be around 2 or 3 hits for your basic enemies because their health is built around what weapons you can obtain and when. But this game still gives you 100 health so therefore the regular shotgun is like throwing pebbles at your enemies and the rocket launcher can and will kill people in two shots.

They didn’t even think about the fact that your weapons get better the further you progress in Quake, and that it would be a stupid idea to just randomly scatter them through the maps to where when you get the best weapon (The Rocket Launcher), you’re set for the rest of the game. I am 100% aware this is already a flaw in Quake’s multiplayer already, but it still plays into this game and that doesn’t make it okay.

This game overall just feels lazily put together so Valve can feel like they made their own rendition of Quake, the game can be fun but the horribly balanced weapons will be your worst complaint.

The game’s $4.99, but I would just buy Half-Life, Day of Defeat, or even Ricochet. But this is still good to have if you already own all of Valve’s other Gold Source games.

reviewText:
Deathmatch Classic is a multiplayer DM action on HL1 engine, copying almost one to one Deathmatch of Quake 1. It was a free modification that came with patch for Half-Life back when it had retail release, yet as of right now it's being sold serapately on Steam.

And I must announce first, the Internet community here is almost dead. Not worth the purchase, I am afraid. Most often, you will see a list of completely empty servers, only sometimes getting 1-3 players playing on one server.

But yes, what you see here is almost complete copy of Quake 1 Deathmatch experience - a Valve's tribute of it, with same weapons, same maps even, close textures. But it's now shinier and a bit slower-paced. You get same maps. You get same weapons, but they look quite HD compared to Quake 1 style. You know them, shotguns, nailguns, grenade and rocket launchers. And as you know, rocket launcher is really the best weapon here, can't really hope to hit all time with weak projectile weapon that is Nailgun, while Rockets provide heavy-damaging splash effect anywhere you point at. Another thing, is that high-ping is quite unfriendly in this game, you can only hope to do damage with rockets. So yes, Rocket Launcher is overpowered and main thing there, like in Quake 1.
Otherwise, classic Arena formula. Stock, shoot, then run and restock. It's quite fun to duel, combatting and juggling with rockets and then getting away to restock health and armor, taking best on map.
Now, if only it wasn't so dead...
